Situation1: A serious situation has come up in the family, and the grandmother's presence is needed.
Situation2: They occasionally tidy up visible clutter and do light cleaning in shared spaces.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my daughter’s message still glowing on the screen: “Mom, can you come over? It’s urgent.” My heart squeezed. My grandson had been sick all week, and now things sounded worse. I knew they needed me—my daughter always said my presence calmed the kids, and I wanted nothing more than to be there, to hold my grandson’s hand and reassure my daughter.

But as I looked around the apartment, I saw the mess left behind by the tenants. Crumbs on the counter, muddy footprints in the hall, and a bathroom that needed more than a quick wipe. My supervisor had already reminded me last week: “We need to keep the place spotless, especially the shared spaces.” I’d only managed light cleaning lately, and I knew another complaint could cost me this job.

I felt torn in two. My family needed me, but so did my work. I could almost hear my supervisor’s disappointment, and at the same time, I pictured my grandson’s pale face. My hands trembled as I weighed the expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which way to turn.
